{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3375448,"name":"Falon Clark","username":"Tatiman-Dev","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tatiman-dev/{size}/236095_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-27T20:48:33.834Z","cooked":"

Does anyone have info on REV throughbore encoder drift? I’ve had a lot of problems with it this year and last year on our bot, but never like, done it in a controlled environment, but I just did. 15 rotations forward, then 15 rotations back, and “zero” shifted by about 0.035 rotations, thats like 12 degrees. I’ve now noticed drift on 3 seperate encoders, which I believe were each purchased seperately, multiple months apart, with drift. This is super weird does anyone have any ideas? (used in dutycycle mode with the roborio’s DIO ports)

Nothing useful to add but my old team has also had problems with this.

Two additional tests you might want to try:

  • Run the same throughbore encoder into the roboRIO DIO ports and use the Encoder class in relative mode. If the problem still occurs that might indicate something is slipping inside the encoder. If it doesn’t, that might indicate something in the generation of the absolute signal or decoding of the absolute signal
  • Run the same throughbore encoder into a SparkMax or TalonSRX to see if it’s the absolute signal decoding in the roboRIO.

@AdamHeard is the order of magnitude error you measured in the throughbore similar to what is described above?

Kraken 2.0 speculation Motors
Ooops. Having measured the rev through bore against a very high end encoder, I found about twice their published error and a pretty appreciable amount of nonlinearity.

Linking this in:

REV Throughbore Absolute Error Badly Out of Tolerance Sensors
Overview After experiencing some weird behavior I created a test jig and measured the angles returned by the absolute output of two REV Throughbore encoders and found significantly out of spec error. TLDR: 2 REV Throughbores appear to have a maximum absolute angle error ~10 times higher than the value specified in the datasheet and I have no clue why. How we found it We’ve been testing our MAXSwerve modules and noticed occasionally at least on of our modules would look slightly off on the stee…
